intro: Bupleurum mareoticum, commonly known as the Nile angelica, is a flowering plant native to the Nile River valley in Egypt. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found near water bodies. Bupleurum mareoticum has been historically used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
